roll.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if something rolls, especially something round, or if you roll it, it moves along a surface by turning over and over
roll.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The ball rolled into the street.
One of the eggs rolled off the counter.
Roll the chicken breasts in flour.
roll.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to turn your body over one or more times while lying down, or to turn someone else’s body over
roll.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The children rolled down the hill, laughing.
I tried to roll him onto his side.
roll.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to make something into the shape of a tube or ball
roll.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Would you like the paper rolled or folded?
Roll the dough into small balls.
roll.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to make something flat by rolling something heavy over it
roll.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Pizza dough should be rolled thinly.
roll.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to fold the sleeves or legs of something that you are wearing upwards, so that they are shorter
roll.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: His sleeves were rolled above his elbows.
roll.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to move on wheels, or make something that has wheels move
roll.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Her car was slowly rolling away from the curb.
The waitress rolled the dessert trolley over to our table.
roll.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to move over a surface smoothly without stopping
roll.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to move continuously in a particular direction
roll.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: Mist rolled in from the sea.
We watched the waves rolling onto the beach.
roll.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if you roll dice, you throw them as part of a game
roll.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if drums or thunder roll, they make a long low series of sounds
roll.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: if a machine such as a film camera or a printing press rolls, it operates
roll.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: There was silence as the cameras started to roll.
roll.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: if a ship or plane rolls, it leans one way and then another with the movement of the water or air
roll.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to make your own cigarette, using tobacco or marijuana and special paper
roll.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: Ben rolled a joint (=a cigarette containing marijuana) and lit it.
It’s cheaper to roll your own (=make your own cigarettes).
roll.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: to move your shoulders forward, up, and back down
roll.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: to move your eyes around and up, especially in order to show that you are annoyed or think something is silly
roll.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: Lucy rolled her eyes as Tom sat down beside her.
roll.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: to rob someone, especially when they are drunk and asleep
roll.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: Kids on the streets rolled drunks for small change.
roll.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a piece of paper, camera film, money etc that has been rolled into the shape of a tube
roll.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I used up three rolls of film on holiday.
There’s a new roll of silver foil in there.
roll.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a small round loaf of bread for one person
ham/cheese etc roll British English (=one that is filled with ham, cheese etc)
roll.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: hot soup served with crusty rolls
the electoral roll British English,  the (voter) rolls American English (=a list of the people who are allowed to vote)
roll.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Three senators missed the roll call.
Thompson said he had cut welfare rolls by 39%.
a school with 300 pupils on the roll
roll.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: the action of throwing dice as part of a game
roll.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: If you get a 7 or 11 on your first roll, you win.
roll.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a thick layer of skin or fat, usually just below your waist
roll.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: the rolls of fat on her stomach
roll.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: a movement in which you roll forward or back in a controlled way with your body curled so that your head is near your feet, often done as part of a sport
roll.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: the action of turning your body over one or more times while lying down
roll.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: a young horse having a roll in the field
roll.translation[1].definitions[7].defin: a long low fairly loud sound made by drums etc
roll.translation[1].definitions[7].examp: There was a roll of thunder, and the rain started pelting down.
roll.translation[1].definitions[8].defin: the movement of a ship or plane when it leans from side to side with the movement of the water or air
